page.title: 02Hallow-e'en
page.content: Hallow-e'en means "Holy Eve" and is celebrated on the 31st of October. After school finishes all the children run down to the village and visit each of the shops in turn. The shopkeepers throw out money, sweets, nuts and fruit. All the children scramble for them and get as much as they can. In the evening all the children go out guising. They dress up in funny clothes, carrying turnip lanterns and go to people's houses. When they are asked in they entertain the people by singing a song, reciting a poem or telling a joke. Then they are given sweets, toffee apples or perhaps a small sum of money. By the end of the evening all of the children have bags full of good things to eat to take home with them.
